"You must do the things you think you cannot do."- Elenor Roosevelt

Russellville Independent Schools welcomed back adult team members today at all four campuses to kick-off the 2020-2021 school year.

"Today, August 12, 2020, will be remembered as an historic and somewhat uncanny event- as teachers socially distanced in large commons areas and wore masks to begin final preparations for the new school year. Small group gatherings and conversations were not permitted without following social distancing guidelines. 6 months ago, we never imagined prepping for a brand new school year without being able to collaborate and plan in close proximity with our colleagues. We miss our students and we are saddened that we will not be able to begin in-person instruction until after September. BUT, we always find a way to do the things that seem impossible. We will continue to work tirelessly and plan to meet the needs of our students as best we can during the COVID-19 pandemic." - Cassie Reding, Instructional Facilitator 6th-12th Grades

Tomorrow, July 25th, Mrs. Esther White will celebrate her hundred and first birthday, and today she was recognized by the Russellville Independent School district as being the oldest- living former teacher from the district. Mrs. White was hired at the beginning of the school year in 1953 to fill a sixth grade vacancy, with five years of experience under her belt. Her salary was $209 per month in 1953. Mrs. White went on to devote 31 years of her life to teaching students in the Russellville Independent School system. On behalf of Russellville Independent Schools, we send a special thank you and congratulations to Mrs. Esther White and her beloved family. We are grateful for her service to our community and wish her a very Happy Birthday!

Mrs. White was also honored with a plaque presented by Russellville Mayor Mark Stratton, proclaiming July 24, 2020 "Esther White Day" in the city of Russellville.

As a display of appreciation for all of the staff’s hard work, a luncheon was held on Friday, May 8, expressing thanks from some of our most dedicated Panther Alumni, Ann Page McReynolds, Jean Reynolds, Jean Oberhausen, and Mary Lucy Franklin. The meal was very much appreciated by all. We R Panthers!

Tonya Davenport is with Ryan Davenport and 28 others.
March 27 at 3:55 PM ·

It's been a very long 2 weeks. I'm so grateful to work for a school who came together today to participate in a Wave Parade" for our students. It was a long ride trying, our best to cover as much area as possible, but it was the best 3 hours I've had in 2 weeks!! Ryan and I got to do this together!!! Coach had his whistle out... LOL!! I miss my co-workers, students, and my normal routine life. Driving around today seeing their smiling faces with excitement, was so delightful! My eyes wanting to water a little bit thinking about these little people being home. Just wondering if they are all healthy, eating good, staying inside, getting help with their NTI packets, and having something to do. I'm so grateful for this day! It was great!!! I can't wait to see them inside our school again, hopefully sooner than later. Best day I've had in 2 weeks! Love my SES fam!!! #SESROCKS #WELOVEANDMISSOURSTUDENTS

post_text: For the first time in over a decade, on Tuesday, Feb. 5-7, Senior, Laura Mullen, traveled to Louisville to participate in the Kentucky Music Educators Association (KMEA) All-State Choir. With an almost perfect score of 99.7, she was the top Soprano in the 3rd District and was accepted into the SSAA (Women’s) choir. She rehearsed for three days with the top choral singers in the state and performed on the 7th of February. Laura remarked on this event by expressing, “This has been the most enjoyable and enriching experience I have ever been a part of. I have loved every second of it, and I learned so much in every single rehearsal. I hope that other members of the Russellville High School Choir will audition next year to have the chance of being in something as incredible as this." This was a great accomplishment and will help Miss Mullen in the future as she works towards a vocal music education degree at Murray State University.

Superintendent, Bart Flener, was excited about the opportunity taken to show appreciation and feed the RISD Transportation, Facilities, and the Food Service Adult Team Members. These folks work diligently each day to provide for our students! #ComeHungryLeaveFull was the theme for the evening, and it appeared that the task was accomplished. On Wednesday, Sept. 11, motivational speaker, Mike Lee, came to the Russellville Middle School and the 6th Grade Academy to speak to the students regarding the “Power Word for the month: Resilience”. Not only is Mr. Lee a motivational speaker, he was also a college basketball player. Mr. Lee now works with basketball players from all over to help them achieve their dreams and goals. He shared that these achievements are attained “by tapping into one’s own personal power through mindfulness”, and he teaches them that “win comes with struggle.” The students listened with intent as he shared his own personal experiences about a prior injury, and how he had to accept that the struggle was necessary for him to grow. He pushed through for five years before he was able to fully recover and play basketball again. At the end of the seminar, students were allowed to ask questions, and Mr. Lee was more than happy to answer. We R Resilient!
(Article and pictures by Laura Mullen)

The Barren River District Health Department recently received a grant to purchase signage to support the new House Bill #318 100% Tobacco Free Campus law. Kathy Thweatt began applying for the grant in April. Once it was awarded she worked alongside Danny Perry to develop the design for the signs depicting a Tobacco Free Campus. As the signs were finished, Kathy Thweatt presented them to Russellville Independent Superintendent Bart Flener and Logan County Superintendent Paul Mullins at the Russellville Independent Schools Central Office on Wed., Aug. 28. Both gentlemen stated they were very appreciative of the partnership our schools have with the Health Department and are grateful to Kathy Thweatt for all she does. She stated an organization in Louisville, the “Foundation for a Healthy KY”, has heard about Kathy’s grant and wants to adopt this idea for other districts. Mrs. Thweatt will also be distributing her signs to Butler County Schools on Friday and Edmonson County Schools on Tuesday. We R 100% Tobacco Free Schools!

On Friday, August 8, the Russellville Middle School Lady Panthers softball team had its first game of the season. However, this was more than just a game; it was the honoring of a former coach, sister, and mother who inspired the hearts of many. Ashlee “Cocoa” Collier was a "kind and fierce soul" with a "heart of gold" who was deeply loved by her softball family. Loving words were written by Tonya Davenport as Cass Whitescarver read them aloud for the crowd to hear. The softball team had a flag created in her honor, and it was lifted high that night above the softball field as a prayer was led by Chris Penrod. A moment of silence was shared among her family, friends, and team. “Cocoa” certainly would have been proud as the Lady Panthers secured the win against Bowling Green. She will never be forgotten #NobodyBetter
(Article by Laura Mullen, Student Intern)
